ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

MEDICAL OFFICERS IN CIVIL SERVICE
(Resignations and conditions of work)


    1. Mr P. Govindaswamy: To ask the Minister for Health (a) how many medical officers resigned from the Civil Service in 1977; (b) how many medical officers were attached to the various hospitals as at 30th November, 1977, and whether the number of medical officers in each hospital was sufficient to cope with the workload; and (c) what are the average working hours per week and the number of off days per month for medical officers and housemen, and, if it is not possible for them to work within the required working hours and take their off days weekly, whether he will consider making an alternative arrangement.

     Mr Speaker: Mr P. Govindaswamy.

     Mr Ahmad Haleem (Telok Blangah): Mr Speaker, Sir, Question No. 1.

     The Minister for Health (Dr Toh Chin Chye): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have distributed to Members of the House figures (Cols. 299 - 300) to Question 1(a) and 1(b). I will therefore not repeat them here.
figures - APPENDIX TO ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION NO. 1(Cols. 203-205)


    In answer to Question 1(c), I would like to explain that the hours of work of doctors vary according to the posting. Normally doctors who are working in Outpatient Departments, for example, work office hours and they have a normal week of 42 hours. Those in the hospitals, besides their normal week of 42 hours, are required to perform night duties. If they have a night duty once a week, it will add 15 1/2 hours to the normal 42 hours quota, and if they do have two night-duty performances in a week, it will work out to about 72 hours in a normal week. In the Accidents and Emergency Department the doctors work on shifts and, therefore, they have a 42-hour week but they are given time off for night duties.

Column: 204



    The problem is a very vexing one because night duties are not necessarily applicable to all doctors working in hospitals. In our system we find that housemen and medical officers are asked to perform night duties. This means that they must be within the hospital precincts. Senior doctors, however, are on call which means that they can go home, attend to their family life or attend to their social life, but they have a bleeper and, if necessary, they can be called to the hospital. Sir, I am in sympathy with those who have to perform as many as two night duties in a week, especially those who are in the Department of Obstetrics and Gynaecology. As Members of the House are aware, babies do not tell doctors what time they are supposed to come out into the world. We therefore find that most doctors posted to the Department of Obstetrics and Gynaecology, including the Registrars and Senior Registrars, have a higher mean rate of weekly hours. They range from 68 hours for Registrars and Senior Registrars, 55 hours for Consultants, 78 and 79 hours for medical officers and housemen respectively. The problem, of course, really depends upon manpower. If there are more doctors available who can be rostered for night duty, then the number of hours per week worked by each doctor can be reduced.

    However, I must point out the distinction between hours of work and productivity. During the night, patients do not require much attention as most of them have been treated and attended to during the day. So during the night it is necessary to have only a small number of doctors for emergency calls. That is why they are asked to be within the hospital precincts. In the case of housemen, it has been a tradition that to be on night duty is part of their training. While we can permutate the roster, I am afraid that as of this moment it is not possible to reduce the number of night duties which are already allocated because of the existing staff position. If doctors are unable to perform night duty on a particular day, arrangements can be made for them to have substitutes. I think that is not a problem at all. However, I

Column: 205

do hope to make an in-depth study into this problem, and I do admit that it is an unsatisfactory position.

    In New Zealand medical doctors of all grades are on call and this means that they must be within the precincts of the hospital. It is only the Consultants who are allowed to stay away from the hospital. That would be an excellent pattern for us to follow. So we will have to take some time to work out a re-arrangement of the night duty roster, and if we can have more manpower pitching in, I think the burden will be less both for the medical officers and housemen.

DIPLOMATIC RELATIONS WITH VIETNAM
(Development since hijacking incident)


    2. Mr Hwang Soo Jin asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs whether there has been any further development in our relations with the Vietnamese Government since the hijacking incident in October 1977.

     The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr S. Rajaratnam): Mr Speaker, Sir, relations between Singapore and Vietnam had developed normally, prior to the hijacking incident in October 1977. As Members will recollect, the Vietnamese Vice-Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Phan Hien, came to Singapore in July 1976. A delegation from the Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce visited Vietnam in April 1977, and this was followed by an economic delegation organised by INTRACO in August. So things were developing smoothly until the hijacking incident which created differences between Singapore and Vietnam.

    Of course, we have our respective views on the question of jurisdiction over the hijackers. We, that is, Singapore, still hold to our views and I presume the Vietnamese to theirs. The hijackers have been tried and sentenced.

    As of now, I think relations between Singapore and Vietnam are normal. Direct telephone and telex services between Singapore and Ho Chi Minh City, broken off

Column: 206

since April 1975, were resumed on 1st December, 1977. The office of the Import and Export Corporation of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam in Singapore has continued with its routine activities. Our diplomatic representatives in Third World countries maintain regular contact with each other. I expect relations between the two countries to develop along constructive lines in the coming months.

WORK PERMITS FOR PERMANENT RESIDENTS


    3. Mr S. Dhanabalan asked the Minister for Labour whether, in view of the fact that many small businesses are not prepared to consider employing permanent residents as they want to avoid the trouble of applying for work permits for such persons, he will consider changing the procedure to allow permanent residents to apply directly for work permits without sponsors or employers being involved, and issue work permits on such applications thus enabling permanent residents to find employment more easily.

     The Minister of State for Labour (Mr Sia Kah Hui) (for the Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to inform the hon. Member that permanent residents should have no difficulty in obtaining work permits, as it has been the policy to issue work permits to these persons most liberally. The work permits issued are for two years. The present procedure of applying for work permits is simple and is not troublesome for an employer as it only involves the employer at the initial stage of the application by having to complete one part of the application form. The application is processed promptly by the Work Permit Department and the employer, together with the applicant, will normally be informed of the outcome of the application within a week from the date of receipt of the application.

    Work permits for permanent residents are granted easily. The system gives the Government useful data on the work characteristics of non-citizen workers, including permanent residents. It is useful to continue with the present practice.

WORK PERMITS FOR PERSONS WITH
SINGAPORE CITIZEN FAMILIES


    4. Mr Lee Yiok Seng asked the Minister for Labour whether his Ministry will give favourable consideration to applications for work permits in respect of persons whose spouse and children are Singapore citizens or are holders of the Singapore blue identity card.

     Mr Sia Kah Hui (for the Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Work Permit Scheme for foreign workers is designed to meet our manpower requirements in our effort to sustain continued economic development. Under the policy, applications for work permits from technicians and skilled workers are invariably approved. For those who have acceptable training qualifications or have been certified as skilled by the Industrial Training Board, they will be issued with a 3-year work permit. These 3-year work permit holders will be eligible for permanent residence if they have completed at least two years of employment in Singapore. They may eventually be granted citizenship after satisfying the 10-year residential qualification.

    Applications for work permits from unskilled or semi-skilled workers will also be given if they are for jobs which will further the economic development of the Republic. Thus, applications for jobs in manufacturing factories, shipbuilding and repairing and construction industries will be favourably considered. Our work permit policy must be based more on our industrial and manpower needs than on considerations of family ties of the applicant.

POWER FAILURE ON 17TH JANUARY, 1978


    5. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development and Communications what was the cause of the power failure on 17th January, 1978, and how long it took the authorities to restore the power supply.

     The Minister for National Development and Communications (Mr Lim Kim San): Mr Speaker, Sir, at 9.34 a.m. on 17th January, 1978, a 120 megawatt generator at the Jurong Power Station developed vibration at one of its bearings, and its protective relays tripped it off the system. The resulting system instability caused another 120 megawatt generator, also at the Jurong Power Station, to trip out. The disconnection of these two generating units from the system activated the operation of system automatic under-frequency relays, cutting off power to Toa Payoh, Aljunied, Kallang Basin and Siglap areas. By 10.30 a.m. power had been restored to 50% of the affected areas, and by 11.34 a.m. the situation had returned to normal.

    For the information of Members, under frequency relays are protective devices installed in the system to automatically disconnect loads in pre-selected steps when there is a certain loss of generating capacity

ROADS
(Causes of deterioration)


    7. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for National Development and Communications (a) why so many roads have deteriorated during the recent heavy rains and what are the causes of the deterioration; (b) whether he is satisfied that road surfacing is carried out with proper technique and under adequate supervision; (c) how much money has been spent on the recent road repairs: and (d) whether and what steps he intends to take to minimise damage to the roads during heavy rains in future.

     Dr Tan Eng Liang (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, damage to road pavements occur mainly in bus lanes, bus stops, intersections and tight bends. Observations indicate that oil spillage over a period softens and dissolves the asphalt in road pavements resulting in loss of its

Column: 210

binding quality. With heavy rainfall, water easily penetrates the asphalt film surrounding the stone aggregate, stripping them from the road pavement thus aggravating the damage. In tight bends, the pavement surfaces are highly stressed by turning vehicles and tend to deteriorate faster than straight road sections. In all instances, heavy vehicles and high traffic volumes tend to hasten the deterioration of road pavements.

    The Public Works Department exercises rigid quality control over the materials used for road surfacing and also undertakes strict supervision of the laying of the premixed asphalt concrete. Samples of materials used at every site are taken and sent to the PWD's engineering laboratory for testing. Sub-standard materials are rejected. Financial penalties are imposed for minor departures from the qualities specified. During road resurfacing works, PWD officers maintain standing supervision to ensure that compaction is adequate and the hot mix asphalt concrete has cooled down sufficiently before the road is opened to traffic. Premature opening to traffic will result in some loosening of the surface materials and subsequent deterioration of the road surface.

    For the period April to October 1977, the average monthly expenditure on road patching was approximately $85,000. For November 1977, this rose to $113,000 and could be attributed to the heavy rainfall at that time.

    In 1976, the PWD reviewed the existing asphalt concrete mix design used and experimented with various mix designs with the aim of improving on the asphalt concrete mix that will be used for future road surfacing. Since the beginning of the current fiscal year, an improved mix has been in use. A stiffer grade of bitumen has also been specified. The PWD is in correspondence with various research and highway authorities in other countries, obtaining useful information on how the problem can be solved. The Department has, in addition, initiated systematic scientific studies to determine precisely the factors affecting road surface deterioration.

    214 units of 3-room and 4-room flats in 13 blocks will be offered for sale to the sitting tenants under the Home Ownership Scheme. The flats in Blocks 20 and 21 will not be sold as they are affected by road widening scheme.

    Eight blocks of single-storey Artisan Quarters and shops and six blocks of 3- and 4-storey flats will be demolished for redevelopment. The tenants will be rehoused in the new flats adjoining the Kampong Silat Estate which are scheduled to be completed in the middle of 1978.

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT
BOARD ESTATES
(Role of community service groups
and integration thereof)


    13. Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi asked the Minister for National Development and Communications, since more than 70 per cent of Singapore's population will eventually reside in Housing and Development Board estates, (a) whether Government considers existing social, cultural, recreational, religious and other private associations as having an important role to play in the future Singapore societies in HDB estates; (b) if so, whether the HDB will adopt policies to allow for an orderly integration of such associations into the communities in HDB estates; and (c) what these policies are and what criteria will be used to ensure orderly integration.

     Dr Tan Eng Liang (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, the work of our cultural, recreational, religious and other charitable bodies is important to HDB and non-HDB residents.

    In HDB estates, sites and premises are provided for such bodies to promote their activities. For example, sites are reserved for religious bodies to build their churches, mosques and temples and premises are offered at concessional rentals to associations affected by development programmes in the central area or elsewhere, to enable them to continue their work. Premises at concessional rentals are also offered to organisations of social value which are interested in extending their activities in HDB estates.

     Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi (Kampong Kembangan): Sir, I would like to know whether all these facilities will be extended to all registered associations in the areas affected, or will this be done on a selective basis? If this is to be done on a selective basis, what will be the criteria?

     Dr Tan Eng Liang: Sir, it is obvious that criteria must be exercised in the selection of these registered organisations. Since the number of premises is limited in any

Column: 215

housing estates, consideration for priority will be based on the need or the urgency of resettlement cases, or on the requirements in terms of greater and better usage to a particular housing estate. I am in no position to give the Hon. Member the different criteria exercised. But each case goes before the Allocations Committee and finally it has to get the approval of the HDB.

     Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi: Sir, in my question, I have also asked what criteria will be used to ensure orderly integration. I have received requests from a number of organisations, in particular, constituencies like Kampong Kembangan and Kampong Ubi, and they have been there for more than 20 years. But perhaps because of lack of clearcut policies, these organisations have not been told very clearly whether or not they will be given sites in HDB estates; if so, when will they be given and what will be the terms. I needed clarification on the criteria because should the representatives of these organisations see me again I would be in a better position to explain to them.

     Dr Tan Eng Liang: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have already indicated that there are criteria but each case must be assessed on its own merits. Let me give Members a specific example. I have mentioned the availability of sites for religious organisations. That must be an indication to Members that there are difficulties in allocating sites for priority cases. If a site is available for religious bodies, then a non-resettlement case could tender for the site. The same system is also applicable to other social or cultural organisations.

    As to exactly when a particular case could be resettled or to be considered for priority consideration, the details must be made known to the relevant authority.
